items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is possible through Thursday and into Friday.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected for the remainder of the week and the situation should continue to improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 10/10/24. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.
We expect river levels to remain high until Friday, 11/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 11/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high and rising slowly on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 11/10/2024, especially in the Heyford Bridge and Thrupp areas. Friday is forecast to be mainly dry and Saturday mainly dry with the chance of showers. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/10/24 ,or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high and and rising slowly on the River Windrush as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 11/10/2024 especially in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. Friday is forecast to be mainly dry and Saturday mainly dry with the chance of showers. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels have fallen at the top end of the River Evenlode but are still high further down where levels are high but falling slowly. River levels on the River Glyme are stabilising and starting to fall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 11/10/2024, especially in the Shipton and Woodstock areas. Friday is forecast to be mainly dry and Saturday mainly dry with the chance of showers. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/10/24 or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high, but falling slowly on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/10/24. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the next few days and sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (11/10/2024), or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kym in Bedford Borough and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024.  
Areas most at risk are around the River Kym and River Til from Yelden, and Upper Dean to Hail Weston.    
The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon.
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11th October 2024.

River levels remain high at the Eathorpe river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington. No further rainfall is forecast, although our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is possible.
River levels are high on the River Ray following recent heavy rainfall but are steady and starting to fall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/10/24 especially in the Lower Arncott and Thrupp areas. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are currently stable and starting to fall but are expected to remain high over the next few days and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (11/10/2024), or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, 10/10/2024, especially in the Hannington Bridge area. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and the river levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/10/24. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (11/10/2024), or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 07:30am on Friday 11th October. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 47 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 42 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 4pm today, 11/10/2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are still high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Thursday 10th October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

The forecast is dry for the next 3 days, but levels are still high and steady on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Friday 11th October, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 9am on 11/10/24, or as the situation changes

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Dikler following recent rainfall, but are falling slowly. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today 11/10/2024. Friday is forecast to be mainly dry and Saturday mainly dry with the chance of showers.  River levels are expected to remain high throughout today but continue falling slowly. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne following the recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of further flooding of low lying land and roads in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey is reducing. It is forecast to be a dry day 11/10/24. River levels are slowly falling and we expect this to continue.  

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: The River Nene has been falling steadily today, Thursday 10th October. The B1040 road will be opened once the Highways Authority have been able to inspect the road surface, and carry out any necessary works to ensure the road is passable. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

River levels are high and holding steady in response to recent rainfall. River levels also remain high downstream. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024. Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area. The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11 October 2024.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024.
Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester may also be affected.  
The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon.
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11 October 2024.

River levels are high but beginning to fall in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024.
Areas most at risk are around the Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall.  
The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon.
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11 October 2024.

Further flooding is possible this afternoon as river levels remain high but are beginning to fall due to previous daysÂ rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Flagham Brook, Swill Brook, Hankerton Brook, Hykemeres Stream, Derry Brook, River Key

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are now falling on the Upper River Thames tributaries following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of  flooding remains but is reducing (10/10/2024), especially in the Oaksey area.  The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are falling slowly and we expect this to continue but the river remains sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 9am on 11/10/24, or as the situation changes.

The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon.
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 10th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels are higher due to recent rainfall entering the Broads system being held up by a surge from a low-pressure system within the North Sea. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Friday 11th October, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Weather conditions are expected to continue to improve with some scattered showers possible today. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.53 m and falling slowly. The drain level is 7.22 m and steady. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3 m.

The weather is forecast to be largely dry tomorrow and throughout the weekend.

We are currently unable to pump due to the high river levels, but we have opened the Parrett Relief Channel to help reduce these. Pumping activities will commence as soon as the river levels allow.

We are monitoring the situation closely. Do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water, and be careful using footpaths near local watercourses and flooded areas. Refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures.
 
This message will be updated by 4PM tomorrow, Friday 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but falling slowly on the Bear Brook as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 10/10/2024, especially in the Aylesbury area. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are falling slowly and we expect this to continue. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling on the middle Bristol Avon and Semington Brook. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected for the remainder of the week and the situation should continue to improve.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the evening and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Wellow and Ower has fallen significantly overnight. Only 3mm of rain was recorded at Romsey in the last 24 hours. The current forecast for the next five days is for broadly dry conditions, so the imminent risk of flooding should continue to recede. We will monitor the forecast and will communicate any elevated flood risk when necessary.

items.description: River Ock from Watchfield to Abingdon, and also the Letcombe Brook at Wantage, Grove and East Hanney
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but steady on the River Ock as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, today 10/10/2024, especially in the Charney Bassett area. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Weather conditions are expected to continue to improve with some scattered showers possible today. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston is still high, but is now slowly falling following Tuesday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens, and roads, including North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. In Hellingly, the Bull River in particular remains higher than normal, but has already fallen significantly. Only minimal flood impacts are expected in Hellingly, affecting fields and roads. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rainfall is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. All rivers will continue to fall. The Cuckmere River in Alfriston should return nearer to a normal level by Friday afternoon (11/10/2024). Please plan to avoid driving on routes susceptible to flooding, including North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 11/10/2024.

The Western Rother is high in Fittleworth, and higher than normal at Lodsbridge, near Selham. However, the Western Rother is now falling along its length. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens of mill properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham and in Fittleworth should continue to slowly ease through Thursday. River levels between Liss and Midhurst are already near normal. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. The river will continue to slowly fall. At Lodsbridge, near Selham, the river should return nearer to a normal level by Friday morning (11/10/2024). In Fittleworth, the river is unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until next week. Residual flood impacts may continue to affect some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is possible.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels in the Great Stour and local watercourses remain high this afternoon and into tomorrow (11th October 2024), but are falling and will continue to do so over the next couple of days. 
Flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible, however property flooding is not expected. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater.

Scattered showers are possible into this evening, but weather conditions are expected to continue to improve and remain largely dry for the next couple of days. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on 11th October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. 

The risk of flooding from the River Clyst and Culm and their tributaries has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston is still high, but now slowly falling, following Tuesday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and roads; including North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. A Flood Alert remains in force to describe the situation. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. The river will continue to slowly fall and should return nearer to a normal level by Friday afternoon (11/10/2024). Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if new instances of property flooding are expected.

River levels remain high but are starting to fall slowly at both the Tewkesbury Upper Pound river gauge and the Mythe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today, 10/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 

Predicted peaks:- Mythe peaked at 2.75m at 11am this morning, Thursday 10/10/2024. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 9am on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are high and holding steady in response to recent rainfall. River levels also remain high downstream. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024. 
Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.  
The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11 October 2024.

River levels have peaked and are beginning to fall at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 9am on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly have fallen significantly. Only minimal and residual flood impacts are now expected to affect fields and roads. A Flood Alert remains in force. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. The rivers should continue to fall a little further. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Residual flood impacts may continue to affect some roads. Please take care driving routes vulnerable to flooding. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if property flooding is expected.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are now falling on the River Pang following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of  flooding remains but is reducing (10/10/2024), especially in the Tidmarsh and Sulham areas. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. River levels are falling and we expect this to continue. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. 
We continue to monitor the situation

This flood warning is no longer in force. River levels at Woodhouse mill have fallen and are continuing to do so. No further significant rainfall is expected in the coming days and we are continuing our pumping operations on site. We are closely monitoring the situation and will re-issue this flood warning if necessary.

The River Adur is still higher than normal, but now slowly falling, following Tuesday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads, should continue to slowly ease through Thursday. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. The river will continue to slowly fall and should return nearer to a normal level by Friday morning (11/10/2024). Residual flood impacts may continue to affect some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding becomes possible.

The River Ouse through Barcombe remains higher than normal, but is now falling following Tuesday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, and rural roads near Barcombe should continue to ease through Thursday. Upstream, nearer Ardingly, river levels have fallen further and are already nearer to a normal level. A few scattered showers are possible Thursday, but very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week and through the weekend. The river will continue to slowly fall and should return nearer to a normal level in Barcombe by Thursday afternoon (10/10/2024). Residual flood impacts may continue to affect some roads, including Barcombe Mills Road. Please take care driving routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding become possible.

High river levels this afternoon may lead to continued flooding.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.
Weather conditions are expected to improve this afternoon but river levels will continue to rise at the Wimborne A31 gauge and Throop gauge until tomorrow morning..
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message if the situation changes.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Weather conditions are expected to continue to improve with some scattered showers possible today We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are rising but starting to stabilise on the River Cole as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/10/2024, especially in the Inglesham area. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are rising slowly on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 10/10/2024, especially in the Buscot, Grafton, Radcot, Rushey and Shifford areas. The rainfall is forecast to clear this morning leaving the rest of Thursday mostly dry. Friday is expected to be dry.  We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as river levels are back below trigger levels.

This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels are falling following the recent heavy rainfall. No further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if necessary.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire

items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible today, 10/10/2024.  Areas most at risk are around Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton. You are advised to move cars out of these flood risk areas. The weather forecast is improving, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon.
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 11 October 2024.

items.description: Bristol Avon (upper) from Chippenham to Melksham
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Weather conditions are expected to improve with drier weather forecast through the week and the situation is expected to improve through the week. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
This flood alert has been removed as river levels in the Seven catchment are back below trigger levels.

floodArea.county: Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Redcar and Cleveland, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed as there is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

Further rainfall is forecast overnight but no further flooding is expected. 

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.  

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 10th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels are higher due to recent rainfall entering the Broads system being held up by a surge from a low-pressure system within the North Sea. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Friday 11th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 10th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels are higher due to recent rainfall entering the Broads system being held up by a surge from a low-pressure system within the North Sea.  We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Friday 11th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as the tide has passed.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout this afternoon into tomorrow may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 7:00 PM on 09/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow morning as river levels are forecast to rise due to previous daysÂ rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels are back below trigger levels.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible this evening, 10/10/24, especially in the Godstow area. Thursday and Friday are forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/10/24 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: This alert has been issued as river levels have risen following heavy rainfall over recent days. Areas most at risk include the Upper Derwent around the Low Marishes area. Levels are not of concern elsewhere in the catchment. Levels at Low Marishes are peaking and are expected to fall later today Friday 11/10/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Friday 11/10/2024, or as the situation changes.
